description:
Parathielavia appendiculata is a species of fungus belonging to the phylum Ascomycota. It is a saprobic organism, meaning it derives its nutrients from decomposing organic matter in the environment.

This fungus is characterized by the presence of small, disc-shaped ascocarps (fruiting bodies) that are typically less than 1 millimeter in diameter. The ascocarps are light-colored, often white or pale yellow, and bear appendages or hairs on their surface, which is the source of the species name "appendiculata."

The asci (spore-bearing structures) within the ascocarps are cylindrical or club-shaped, and they contain eight ascospores. The ascospores are hyaline (transparent) and typically ellipsoidal or fusiform in shape.

Parathielavia appendiculata is commonly found growing on decaying plant material, such as fallen leaves or rotting wood, in temperate and tropical regions around the world. It plays a role in the decomposition of organic matter and the cycling of nutrients in the ecosystem.
